ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Inverted organic solar cells comprising low-temperature-processed ZnO films

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Inverted organic solar cells are fabricated using low-temperature-annealed ZnO film as an electron transport layer. Uniform ZnO films were prepared by spin coating a diethylzinc (DEZ) precursor solution in air, followed by annealing at 100 °C. Organic solar cells prepared on these ZnO films with a 1:1 P3HT:PCBM blend as the active layer show a high power conversion efficiency of 4.03 %, which is more than 10 % higher than the PCE of solar cells comprising ZnO prepared via a high-temperature sol–gel route.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Organic solar cells (OSCs) have attracted great attention as a viable alternative renewable energy source due to low cost, large area processability and compatibility with flexible substrates [1–3]. As the power conversion efficiency (PCE) of bulk-heterojunction (BHJ) OSC devices approaches 10 %, long term device stability becomes a major concern [4–6]. In conventional BHJ devices, an active layer consisting of a conjugated polymer as the donor and a soluble fullerene derivative as the acceptor are sandwiched between poly (3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrene sulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS)-coated indium tin oxide (ITO) serving as the anode and a low work function metal as the cathode. Here, PEDOT:PSS acts as an anode buffer layer. However, the strong acidic and hygroscopic nature of PEDOT:PSS was shown to cause interface instabilities and corrosion of ITO [7–9]. Also, typical low work function metals such as Ca or Ba serving as the cathode are easily oxidized by oxygen and moisture upon exposure in air, which causes rapid deterioration of the device performance [10].

To address this problem, inverted device structures have been developed where charge collection is in reversed direction [11–18]. These inverted devices were shown to be more stable and also shown higher absorption when compared to normal devices in BHJ systems [17]. In such the inverted devices, air-stable high work function metals such as Au and Ag serve as the hole collection back electrode [11, 12], and n-type metal oxides such as titanium dioxide (TiOx) [4, 13, 14], Zinc oxide (ZnO) [15–17], or alkali–metal compounds such as cesium carbonate (Cs2CO3) [18] deposited on ITO act as the electron collecting contact. The high electron mobility, environmental stability and high transparency of ZnO compared to other n-type metal oxides make it an ideal electron selective contact in inverted solar cells [19]. In the past years, various fabrication methods like sputtering, sol–gel spin coating, spray pyrolysis, pulsed laser deposition (PLD) or chemical vapor deposition (CVD) have been used to deposit ZnO films of controllable thickness [20–24]. In between all, sol–gel is most commonly used, as it involves solution processing steps suited for low cost large area processing. However, very high temperatures (~350 °C) are usually needed to achieve high charge carrier mobility in sol–gel-processed ZnO layers and to remove residual organic compounds [21]. Such temperatures are not applicable for device processing on flexible plastic substrates.

In this communication, we report an elegant approach to prepare uniform ZnO thin films using moderate annealing temperatures of ~100 °C, and its application as an efficient electron transport layer in inverted solar cells. The preparation of these devices involved spin coating of diethylzinc (DEZ) dissolved in a common organic solvent. There are few publications where DEZ was used as a precursor to form ZnO in the active layer of hybrid solar cells [25, 26]. Malm et al. [27] also used DEZ and water to grow ZnO films by the expensive atomic layer deposition (ALD) technique. So far, neither the usage of DEZ to prepare uniform ZnO thin films nor its application as the electron transport layer in inverted solar cells has been reported. We show that compared to ZnO prepared by the common sol–gel techniques, the usage of DEZ increased the photovoltaic performance of inverted solar cells by about 13.5 % for the well-known P3HT:PCBM system.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: All devices were fabricated on patterned ITO-coated glass substrates. The ITO-coated glass substrates were cleaned in an ultrasonic bath with acetone, detergent, deionized water, isopropyl alcohol and subsequently dried by N2 gas flow. After being dried, the substrates were treated by oxygen plasma for 2 min. Thin layers of ZnO were prepared by two different methods. In the standard sol–gel technique, a ZnO precursor solution was prepared by dissolving zinc acetate dihydrate [Zn(CH3COO)2 2H2O, Aldrich, 99.9 %, 0.5 g] and ethanolamine (NH2CH2CH2OH, 138 μl) in 2-methoxyethanol (CH3OCH2CH2OH, Aldrich, 5 ml), followed by vigorous stirring for 12 h in air to allow for the hydrolysis of the precursor [16]. The resulting sol was then spin cast on the ITO-coated glass substrates, followed by annealing at 200 °C for 1 h during which the precursor gel was transformed into a dense ZnO film by hydrolysis. Alternatively, 0.6 M solution of DEZ in toluene and tetrahydrofuran was spin cast in air at controlled relative humidity of 40 %. The layer was aged for 15 min in air, during and after spin coating, DEZ reacts with ambient moisture to form Zn(OH)2, which is further converted into ZnO by condensation and solvent annealing at 100 °C for 15 min. 50 mg/ml of dichlorobenzene solution containing a 1:1 blend of P3HT (Sepiolid P200 purchased from BASF) with PC60BM (purchased from Solenne) was spin coated at 600 rpm on top of the ZnO films, yielding a blend layer thickness of approximately 230 nm. The sample was then annealed at 110 °C for 10 min. Finally, 10 nm of MoO3 and 100 nm of Ag were deposited through shadow mask by a thermal evaporation. The active area of the devices was 16 mm2. UV–Vis absorption spectra were recorded with a Varian Cary 5000 spectrophotometer. Current density vs Voltage (J–V) characteristics were measured using a Keithley 2400 source meter. Solar cells were characterized by recording J–V characteristics under simulated Air Mass 1.5 gobal (AM 1.5G) illumination with an irradiation intensity of 100 mW/cm2 using an Oriel class A solar simulator. Incidence photon-to-current conversion (IPCE) efficiencies were measured using a home-build system, in which frequency-modulated monochromatic light from a halogen lamp was used, and the current was detected by a Stanford Research Instruments lock-in amplifier. The IPCE setup is calibrated before each measurement by a calibrated Si photodiode from Newport.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussions
Section1.Para:
The architecture and the energy-band diagram of the inverted organic solar cell are illustrated in Fig. 1a and b, respectively. The active layer was formed by blending highly regioregular poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) and [6,6]-phenyl C61-butyric acid methyl ester (PCBM) at a 1:1 blend ratio. MoO3 covered by Ag served as the hole collecting back contact. Since the energy of the valence band edge of ZnO is much lower than of the highest occupied molecular orbitals (HOMOs) of P3HT and PCBM, this layer also serves as a hole-blocking contact.
Fig. 1
Device structure (a) and energy-band diagram (b) of the inverted organic solar cells

The surface topographies of our ZnO thin films were investigated by atomic force microscopy (AFM). AFM images of sol–gel-derived ZnO and films made from DEZ are shown in the Fig. 2a and b, respectively. Uniform ZnO films composed of small grains are observed in both cases, but the grain size is bigger for the DEZ-derived films. The root mean square (RMS) roughness is 2.3 nm for ZnO prepared via the sol–gel process compared to 6.5 nm for ZnO formed from DEZ. The increased roughness of the DEZ-derived layer likely increases the contact area between the ZnO nanoparticles and the active P3HT:PCBM layer, improving electron extraction to the cathode. Also, a higher surface roughness may lead to increased scattering of the incident light into the active layer.
Fig. 2
AFM images of ZnO films on ITO substrates a ZnO derived from sol–gel, b ZnO prepared from DEZ. Both layers had a thickness of approx. 60 nm

The transmission spectra of both sol–gel and DEZ-derived ZnO nanoparticle films on quartz substrates and the absorbance spectrum of a sample with P3HT:PCBM coated onto ZnO prepared from DEZ are shown in the Fig. 3. We tried to keep the thickness of the final ZnO layer to be roughly the same for both preparation methods, approximately 60 nm. In both cases, a high transmittance of beyond 90 % at a wavelength of 550 nm was achieved, but the DEZ-derived ZnO layer exhibited an overall higher transmittance compared across the entire wavelength regions.
Fig. 3
Transmittance spectra recorded on ca. 60 nm thick ZnO films prepared via the sol–gel technique (blue line) and from DEZ (red line) on quartz substrates. The absorbance spectrum of a thermally annealed 230 nm thick P3HT:PCBM (1:1) blend layer on DEZ–ZnO coated on top of a ITO glass substrate is shown with the dark line

Current density vs. Voltage (J–V) characteristics of ITO/sol–gel ZnO/P3HT:PCBM/MoO3/Ag and ITO/DEZ-ZnO/P3HT:PCBM/MoO3/Ag under simulated AM1.5 illumination at 100 mW/cm2 are shown in Fig. 4a. The corresponding device performance parameters are summarized in Table 1. The device with the DEZ-derived ZnO film exhibits a remarkable improvement over the device comprising ZnO made via the sol–gel process. The PCE of the device with DEZ–ZnO device was 4.03 %, compared to 3.55 % for the device with sol–gel ZnO. The maximum efficiency reported so far in the same device configuration using sol–gel-processed ZnO film as the electron transport layer and a MoO3 back contact was 3.09 % as reported by Kyaw et al. [28]. While a PCE of 3.5 % was reported by Hsieh et al. [29] with a PEDOT:PSS anode. Therefore, the PCE of our device with sol–gel-derived ZnO is consistent with previously reported state-of-the-art performance. With DEZ–ZnO, our solar cells outperform these devices, which can be mainly related to a high J SC and FF of 11.26 mA/cm2 and 62.5 %, respectively, compared to 10.83 mA/cm2 and 58.7 % for the devices comprising sol–gel-processed ZnO.
Fig. 4
a Current density–voltage (J–V) characteristics of inverted solar cells comprising sol–gel ZnO (circle) and DEZ–ZnO films (square) under 100 mW/cm2 simulated AM1.5 irradiation. b Corresponding IPCE spectra of the devices in a. c Dark J–V characteristics of inverted solar cells comprising sol–gel-processed ZnO (blue line) and ZnO prepared from DEZ (red line)

The IPCE spectra of device with DEZ–ZnO and sol–gel ZnO are shown in the Fig. 4b. The DEZ–ZnO device exhibits an overall larger IPCE with a maximum value of 63.6 % at 550 nm wavelength. Comparison of the spectra in Figs. 4b and 3 suggests that the higher external quantum efficiency and with that the larger J SC of the DEZ–ZnO-based devices (compared to devices with sol–gel-processed ZnO) origins in part from a higher transmittance of the ZnO layer, resulting in a slightly more efficient incident photon-to-electron conversion. Also, the AFM images showed a larger roughness of the DEZ–ZnO layer, meaning that the interfacial area between the active layer and the electron-extracting electrode is enlarged. A larger extracting interface might lower the overall series resistance of the device and cause the steeper increase of the current with bias close to open-circuit conditions for the device with the DEZ-derived ZnO.

We, finally, like to address the higher FF (and slightly larger V oc) of the devices with DEZ–ZnO electron-transporting layers. We notice that inverted solar cells with DEZ–ZnO exhibit lower dark currents throughout the solar cell working regime (see Fig. 4c). This lower dark current might origin from lower leakage or a better charge selectivity of DEZ–ZnO over sol–gel-processed ZnO. It was shown that high dark currents can cause smaller V
OC and FF [30, 31]. We, therefore, propose that the poorer performances of devices with sol–gel-derived ZnO are partly caused by higher dark currents.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In conclusion, low-temperature (~100 °C) solution-processed ZnO has been successfully applied as electron selective layer in inverted organic solar cells. A PCE of 4.03 % was observed devices with the ZnO prepared from DEZ as the precursor, compared to 3.55 % for devices comprising sol–gel-processed ZnO. We attributed the overall better device performance of the former device to a higher transmittance of the DEZ–ZnO layer, increases the amount of light reaching the active layer, and superior electrical properties. We, finally, like to emphasis that the low processing temperature of the DEZ–ZnO layer allows for the preparation of inverted layer stacks on flexible plastic ITO substrates.

Acknowledgments.SimplePara: B. P is grateful to the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation for providing a Humboldt research fellowship.
